title: 113_hr2016
content: The "Military Justice Improvement Act of 2013" is the short title of this Act. It modifies the authority to determine to proceed to trial by court-martial on charges of offenses with authorized maximum sentence of confinement of more than one year. The Act modifies the authority to determine trial by court-martial for offenses with a maximum sentence of more than one year under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The Act modifies the authority to determine trial by court-martial for offenses with a maximum sentence of more than one year under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The disposition of charges is subject to specific requirements and limitations, with the decision to try charges by court-martial made by a designated commissioned officer of the Armed Forces. The Act modifies the authority to determine trial by court-martial for offenses with a maximum sentence of more than one year under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The designated officer must have significant trial experience and be outside the chain of command of the accused. The Act modifies the authority to determine trial by court-martial for offenses with a maximum sentence of more than one year under the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The designated officer must have significant trial experience and be outside the chain of command of the accused. The determination to try charges by court-martial shall be binding on any convening authority for a trial by court-martial on such charges. The determination whether to proceed to trial by court-martial must be free from unlawful influence. The decision not to proceed to trial by general or special court-martial does not affect the authority of commanding officers to refer charges for trial by summary court-martial or impose non-judicial punishment. The Secretaries of the military departments must revise policies and procedures to comply with article 15 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. The General Counsel of the Department of Defense will review the policies for uniformity. The Department of Defense will review revised policies and procedures to ensure uniformity among military departments and prevent any unconstitutional policies. The Secretary of Defense will recommend changes to the Manual for Courts-Martial for compliance. Within 180 days, a report on necessary revisions will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary of Defense will recommend modifications to the Uniform Code of Military Justice and the Manual for Courts-Martial within 180 days. The changes will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act and apply to charges preferred under article 30 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. SEC. 3. The Manual for Courts-Martial will be amended to remove the consideration of the character and military service of the accused in the initial disposition of offenses within 180 days of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. Changes will be made to the officers authorized to convene general and special courts-martial. The Manual for Courts-Martial will be amended to remove certain officers from the chain of command of the accused or victim. Officers in specific offices or of O-6 rank and higher can now have this responsibility. The Manual for Courts-Martial will be amended to prevent certain officers from convening a court-martial if they are in the chain of command of the accused or victim. Each Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces specified in paragraph (5) of section 822(a) of title 10, United States Code, shall establish an office to convene general and special courts-martial. Each Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces will establish an office to convene general and special courts-martial. The office will detail judges and members of courts-martial as specified in the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Personnel for each office will consist of Armed Forces members and civilian personnel assigned by the Chief of Staff concerned. SEC. 5. DEADLINE FOR MILITARY JUDGE TO CALL GENERAL AND SPECIAL COURTS-MARTIAL INTO SESSION. In cases of trial by general or special court-martial, the military judge must convene the court within 90 days of deciding to try the charges. SEC. 6. MODIFICATION OF AUTHORITIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF CONVENING AUTHORITIES IN TAKING ACTIONS ON THE FINDINGS AND SENTENCES OF COURTS-MARTIAL. In amending section 860(c) of title 10, United States Code, written justification is required for certain actions on sentences in court-martial proceedings. Additionally, convening authorities are prohibited from dismissing or changing guilty findings of lesser included offenses without proper justification. The amendments to section 860(c) of title 10, United States Code, prohibit convening authorities from dismissing or changing guilty findings without proper justification in court-martial proceedings. These amendments will take effect upon the enactment of the Act and apply to findings and sentences reported to convening authorities under article 60 of the Uniform Code of Military Justice. Commanding officers must take immediate action upon receiving a report of a sexual offense involving a member of the Armed Forces in their chain of command. The required action is to refer the report to the appropriate criminal investigation office for further investigation. SEC. 8. Monitoring and assessing the implementation and efficacy of the Military Justice Improvement Act of 2013 and its amendments.
